title: Rewrite Graph view with proper dependency visualization
description:
# Rewrite Graph View with Proper Dependency Visualization

## Current Implementation Analysis

### Backend (handlers.rs:289-470)
- Loads all issues, builds dependency graph via topological sort (BFS)
- Groups nodes by level based on dependency depth
- Fixed grid positions: left-to-right per level, top-to-bottom for levels
- Static SVG with positions calculated server-side (~180 lines)

### Frontend (graph.html)
- Static SVG rendered server-side via Askama template
- Type filters (epic, feature, bug, task, chore)
- Expand/collapse buttons for epics with children
- In-page JavaScript (~110 lines, not modular TypeScript)

## Problems with Current Implementation

### Layout Issues
1. Fixed grid layout doesn't scale with many nodes (horizontal overflow)
2. No edge-crossing minimization - lines overlap confusingly
3. All nodes shown at once is overwhelming for large projects
4. Expand/collapse doesn't re-layout (just hides nodes in place)

### Interactivity Limitations
1. No pan/zoom for large graphs
2. No node dragging for manual repositioning
3. Static positions calculated once on server load

### Visual Issues
1. Edge arrows overlap nodes when dense
2. Straight lines cross over other nodes
3. No distinction between dependency types (parent-child vs blocks)

### Data Model Confusion
1. Mixes parent-child relationships with blocking dependencies
2. Dot-notation parsing (nacre-3hd.1) for implicit parent-child is fragile

---

## Proposed Approach: Simplified Hierarchical Tree

**Recommendation**: Don't try to visualize all dependency types in one graph. Instead:

### Phase 1: Epic Tree View (Simple)
- Show epics as collapsible tree nodes (like file explorer)
- Children nested under parent epics
- Click to expand/collapse
- Status indicators (colored dots)
- Link to issue detail on click

**Benefits**: Simple, performant, clear hierarchy

### Phase 2: Dependency Overlay (Optional)
- On hover/focus, show which issues block/are blocked by selected issue
- Highlight edges only for selected node
- Avoids visual clutter of showing all edges at once

---

## Implementation Options

### Option A: HTML/CSS Tree (Recommended)
- Use `<ul>/<li>` with CSS for indentation
- Collapsible via existing list.ts toggle pattern
- No external libraries needed
- Server-side rendered, progressive enhancement

### Option B: D3.js Force-Directed
- Dynamic layout, pan/zoom
- Better for complex graphs
- Adds ~100KB dependency
- More complex to implement

### Option C: Dagre/ELK Layered Layout
- Proper DAG algorithm, minimizes crossings
- Requires JS library
- Good middle ground

---

## Suggested Implementation (Option A)

1. **Remove current SVG-based graph** (~180 lines backend, ~110 lines JS)
2. **Create tree template** similar to epics.html structure
3. **Reuse list.ts** expand/collapse logic
4. **Add to navigation.ts** for keyboard nav (j/k to move, Enter to expand)
5. **Filter by status** (open only, all, etc.)

### Data Structure
```
Epic 1
├── Task 1.1 (open)
├── Task 1.2 (in_progress)
└── Task 1.3 (closed)
Epic 2
└── Feature 2.1
    ├── Task 2.1.1
    └── Bug 2.1.2
Standalone Task (no parent)
```

### Blocked-by Indicator
- Small icon/badge showing "blocked by X" count
- Click to see blockers in tooltip or side panel

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Tree view shows epics with expandable children
- [ ] Status indicated visually (color dot or badge)
- [ ] Keyboard navigation works (j/k/Enter)
- [ ] Filter by issue type
- [ ] Click navigates to issue detail
- [ ] Responsive (no horizontal overflow)
- [ ] Blocked issues have visual indicator

- PRD requirement: UI latency should be <100ms for local actions

- Essential for performance tuning and monitoring

title: Evaluate askama vs minijinja performance for templating
description:
COMPLETED: Created comprehensive template performance benchmark

What was implemented:

1. Comprehensive Benchmark Suite (benches/template_comparison.rs)
- Askama Tests: Simple list (100 items), Complex list (500 items)
- Minijinja Tests: Simple list (100 items), Complex list (500 items)  
- Compilation Overhead: Runtime compilation vs template creation
- Scalability: Tests with 10, 50, 100, 500, 1000 items
- Memory Efficiency: 100 repeated renders test

2. Key Results from Initial Tests:
- Askama Simple List (100 items): ~11.3 µs per render
- Minijinja Compilation: ~8.1 µs (template compilation overhead)
- Askama Template Creation: ~1.6 ns (essentially zero overhead)

3. Technical Implementation:
- Uses criterion.rs for accurate benchmarking
- Realistic test data matching Nacre's issue structure
- Proper JSON serialization for Minijinja compatibility
- Clean separation of Askama vs Minijinja test modules

4. Benchmark Categories Covered:
✅ Template rendering performance with realistic data sizes
✅ Compilation overhead comparison (runtime vs compile-time)  
✅ Scalability testing across different data volumes
✅ Memory efficiency with repeated renders
✅ Both simple and complex template scenarios

Usage:
cargo bench --bench template_comparison

title: Embed static assets into binary
description:
Embed CSS and JS files into the binary at compile time to enable single-binary deployment.

**Current state:**
- Uses tower_http::ServeDir to serve from --static-dir
- Requires frontend/public/ directory at runtime

**Target state:**
- Use include_str!() or rust-embed crate to embed:
  - style.css (~18KB)
  - app.js (~8KB)
- Serve from routes like /static/style.css, /static/app.js
- Remove --static-dir CLI argument
- Single binary can run from any directory

**Implementation options:**
1. include_str!() - simple, built-in
2. rust-embed crate - more features (compression, caching headers)

**Benefits:**
- Run nacre from any repo with .beads/ folder
- No need to locate/copy static files
- Simpler deployment
close_reason: Implemented: embedded static assets using include_str!(), removed --static-dir argument

title: Review and Optimize Frontend Assets (JS/CSS)
description:
# Objective
Review and optimize frontend assets to improve maintainability and reduce binary size.

# Analysis of style.css
## ✅ Strengths
1.  **CSS Variables**: Extensive use of `:root` variables for theming.
2.  **Logical Grouping**: Well-structured and commented sections.
3.  **Modern CSS**: Proper use of Flexbox, Grid, and responsive queries.

## ⚠️ Areas for Improvement
1.  **Dead Code**: Legacy classes like `.vectorian-header` and `.detail-header` are unused or hidden.
2.  **Redundancy**: Repetitive selectors for card types and status badges.
3.  **No Minification**: Files are embedded raw, increasing binary size.

# Actionable Tasks
1.  **Cleanup**: Remove `.vectorian-header`, `.detail-header`, and other unused styles.
2.  **Consolidate**: Refactor repetitive CSS rules (e.g., status colors) using shared classes or variables.
3.  **Minify**: Implement a build step (using Bun or scripts) to minify `style.css` and `app.js` before they are embedded by Rust.
